intro: Quercus obscurirhachis, commonly known as the dark-stemmed oak, is a species of flowering plant in the beech family, Fagaceae. It is native to the eastern United States, particularly in the Appalachian region, where it thrives in moist, acidic soils. The tree has a distinctive appearance, with dark, ridged bark and elliptical leaves that are typically glossy green on top and hairy underneath. Its acorns are small and have a broad, scaly cap, which is characteristic of many oak species. This plant plays an important ecological role in its habitat, providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
